DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Down
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices fell Friday in abbreviated pre-holiday trading on a lower dollar overseas, concerns over Japanese interest rates and a buoyant report on U.S. durable goods orders. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond declined 5-16 point, or $3.13 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, jumped to 7.88 percent from 7.85 percent late Thursday. The credit markets shut down at 1 p.m. EST in advance of the Christmas and Hanukkah holidays. William V. Sullivan, director of money-market research for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said dealers sold bonds in an effort to reduce their portfolios before the end of the year. He said a drop in the dollar in overseas trading also spurred some selling, as did concern that Japan may raise its key lending rate by half a percentage point over the long holiday weekend. The U.S. financial markets are closed Monday for Christmas. Economists said Friday's report showing orders for durable goods _ costly items expected to last more than three years _ up 5.1 percent in November caused an immediate selloff. The increase was the biggest in a year and averted the first three-month drop since mid-1986. The November durable goods gain was an exception to recent evidence that the U.S. manufacturing sector is in a severe slowdown. `It seemed to suggest that although there are pockets of weakness in the economy, we're not in a position that would indicate that a recession is at hand,'' Sullivan said. An economic slowdown generally boosts demand for long-term fixed-income investments such as bonds, which are seen as a hedge against hard times. Kathleen Camilli, a money-market economist with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said the increase in durable goods orders was sharply higher than economists' projections ranging from no increase to up 0.5 percent. In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices of short-term government issues fell 7-32 point to \ point, intermediate maturities were down 5-16 point to 13-32 point, and long-term issues were 9-32 point lower, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 3.36 to 1,194.16. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.82 percent as the discount gained 3 basis points to 7.58 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 7.83 percent as the discount increased 7 basis points to 7.44 percent. Yields on one-year bills jumped to 7.69 percent as the discount rose 5 basis points to 7.16 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, down from 8\ percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 93}, down 1-32 point. The average yield to maturity held at 7.22 percent late Thursday.
